newsitem.title: EGYPT: Suez Cement to go on sale through GDR.
newsitem.headline: Suez Cement to go on sale through GDR.

text.p: National Bank of Egypt (NBE) will sell all or most of its shares in Suez Cement through global depositary receipts (GDRs) in a sale led by ING Barings, Cairo brokers and businessmen said on Wednesday.
The GDR will be the second ever for an Egyptian stock. In July NBE sold stock worth $119 million in Commercial International Bank (CIB) through a GDR listed on the London stock exchange.
Mahmoud Abdel Aziz, chairman of the state-owned bank, told an investment conference in Cairo: "Yesterday we launched the second GDR in Egypt and I'm confident it will be a success."
He declined to name the company or go into details but the brokers and businessmen said he meant Suez Cement, in which NBE holds about 15 percent of the shares.
The company has a market value of about two billion pounds ($600 million), with 49 million shares and a market price on Wednesday of about 41.90 pounds a share.
The brokers said they expected that the depositary for the GDRs would be Bankers Trust Company, which performs the same function for the CIB GDRs.
They said NBE arranged the deal with ING Barings on the sidelines of the investment conference, of which ING Barings was a sponsor. Bankers Trust is a co-sponsor.
Suez Cement announced on Wednesday that it made pre-tax profits of 151 million pounds in the first half of 1996, compared with 146 million in the same period of 1995.
Sales in the period were worth 237 million pounds, compared with 216 million in the first half of 1995, it added.
